response.answer_text: Instead of directly answering the question, I propose the following experiment. Do you have an expensive smartphone? Or some eggs? A pricey antique vase? Or maybe you are the proud new parent of a baby? Let me borrow your phone, eggs, vase, or baby. I am going to stand on the hard concrete sidewalk, hold one arm outstretched horizontally, and hold your object in the palm of my upturned hand. Then I will turn my hand 180°, palm facing the ground. Will you be bothered if I do that? I suspect you will be disgruntled within seconds. “Gravity” is the name for this phenomenon of things falling to the ground, of weight, of dense fluids sinking to the bottom of containers with lighter fluids resting on top. That’s fine for regular human activities on the surface of Earth. When we fall freely, such as in a broken elevator, sky-diving, or riding NASA’s “vomit comet” airplane, gravity effectively disappears. Does that mean gravity isn’t real? No, just that gravity as we know it in everyday life, and motion, are entangled in some way that took the brightest scientists of the late 19th Century and early 20th, including Ernst Mach, Loránd Eötvös and Albert Einstein, to figure out. Even in free fall, there is a reality to gravity which is subtle but fundamental. Imagine falling in an elevator from way up high. (BTW, never buy your elevator cables from Cheapco Ropes Inc.) You have two marbles, which you hold in mid-air, one in each outstretched hand, like I held your antique vase. Let go. The marbles just hover in mid-air, no different from what you see astronauts do on the space station. Except - each marble is heading toward the center of the Earth, moving on radial lines to that center. They move toward each other. If you’re falling from 3,953.2 miles from the center of the Earth, to its surface at 3,963.2 miles (at the equator; of course being wealthy scientists we do our work on tropical islands) - the motion of the marbles toward each other is slight.  If you put the marbles vertically, one near the bottom of the elevator and the other near the top, they’ll move apart slightly. Earth’s gravity is stronger closer to its center, so the lower marble falls a tiny bit faster. The top marble is pulled slight less. The elevator is pulled at an acceleration averaging between that at the top and at the bottom. If your elevator was made out of whipped cream instead of iron, it would stretch out vertically.  (photo credit: NASA Goddard, Arizona State Univ.) Careful measurement of the moving-toward acceleration of horizontally separated marbles, or the moving-together acceleration of the vertically separated marbles, is a direct measure of the Riemann Tensor. Since the publication of Einstein’s General Theory of Relativity decades ago, the Riemann Tensor has been interpreted as a measure of curved space-time. Mostly, for practical situations Humans get themselves into, it’s mostly a matter of nonuniform time flow, and less a matter of curved space. Whether falling near Earth, or stationary, or in orbit, or whooshing upward in a rocket, this moving-together along one or more directions, and moving-apart perpendicularly, is irreducible, always present, always real. It is the most real form of gravity known in physics. It is this effect that Einstein’s field equation [math]G_{\alpha\beta}=8\pi T_{\alpha\beta}[/math] deals with - aside from some mathematical details - the G is a measure of curvature of space-time, and T indicates where there’s mass/energy/pressure/momentum. If we compare to electromagnetism, we see T as being like charge, and G a field which falls off with distance. [math]G[/math] actually falls off as [math]r^{-3}[/math]. It’s related to the gradient of the “connection coefficients” [math]\Gamma^{\alpha}_{\beta\gamma}[/math] which describe influences of curvature on paths of moving objects. On Earth, this may be identified as gravitational acceleration, the good ol’ lower case [math]g=9.8 m/s^2[/math] familiar from basic first year physics. It falls off as [math]1/r^2[/math]. Along the path of an object moving freely, with no rockets engines or wind resistance or anything, the [math]\Gamma^{\alpha}_{\beta\gamma}[/math] can be set to zero. But only right there along that object’s space-time path. They won’t be zero nearby. This is the mathematical way of describing the moving-together or moving-apart of the two marbles. How the connection coefficients vary over distance, their gradient, is the curvature of space-time, quantified by the Riemann Tensor [math]R^\alpha_{\beta\gamma\delta}[/math] or Einstein Tensor [math]G_{\alpha\beta}[/math]. The [math]\Gamma^{\alpha}_{\beta\gamma}[/math] are in turn a sort of gradient of the metric, [math]g_{\alpha\beta}[/math], for which the time-time component [math]g_{00}[/math] incorporates the ordinary gravitational potential, which falls off as [math]1/r[/math]. I describe this math, not to show off fancy math, but to make a point: even though “gravity,” as we mean it in every day life, identifiable as the [math]\Gamma[/math], can be made to disappear just by falling or going into orbit, there’s still something real which persists, which is the changing of [math]\Gamma[/math] from place to place, identifiable with the Riemann and Einstein tensors, which you cannot make zero except by being far, far, far away from any form of energy, matter or momentum. The curvature of space-time is real, as real as the oceans’ tides following the Moon, and is widely accepted by almost all physicists. (There are always a few hold-outs, weirdos, and geniuses trying other ideas.) Many experiments have matched the predictions of theory, while alternative theories assuming flat space always lead to mismatches with experiment. Some experiments which have verified Einstein’s curved space-time: Eddington’s observation of star positions near the Sun during an eclipseDrift in Mercury’s eccentric orbitComparison of atomic clocks sitting on the ground vs. flying around in a jet plane or rocket. Look up “Gravity Probe A”.Direct measurement of the Shapiro delay using Cassini’s transmitter during its cruise to Saturn.Gravity Probe B, with a precision gyroscope using the “roundest object ever made” measured the minuscule shortage of circumference with decreasing radius away from Earth’s center, and the “frame dragging” due to Earth’s spin. ReferenceReal scientists have made these measurements, argued about the details, double-checked their calibrations, and repeatedly come up with consistency with Einsteinian space-time curvature. So is gravity real?

Regardless of what you want to call it, there is a measurable force (prehaps not a force in the classic physics sense) that pulls or attracts us to the earth. The best way I've seen of demonstrating this I think I read elsewhere on Quora;it goes something like this: Take a set of scales (simple kitchen scales work ok). To get a reading on the scale you much compress a spring, to compress it you need to force it down. For example using your hand (which may only weigh a kilo or so) you can apply a force and have the scale read 10 or 20 kg. With a good grip you can maybe get 100kg! So this demonstrates that a force is required to compress the spring and get a reading from the scale. Now ask yourself where the force comes from when you place an object on the scale?There is a force acting on everything to attract us toward the centre of the earth, whether or not you call it gravity or something else is up to you.
